narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: Great class!
Question 10This should be a mandatory class for everyone at F&ES.
Great class overall.

Carol clearly picked the course readings very deliberately, and it showed. I thought the course readings were excellent and, although time consuming, requiring thesis sentences really forced me to closely read and pay attention to the material.
Discussions, and making use of course concepts at the end of the class in the final paper.
The material and concepts discussed.
thesis sentences really make sure you understand the material
Insight into behavior and motivation
The way lectures complimented to form an holistic approach to a complicated subject.
It brings important lenses from which to view any environmental problem. I think every student should have to take this class. It is fabulous!
Class discussions

Well chosen readings, and clear lectures. Also, although the assignment to turn in weekly thesis sentences made the work-load much heavier, I thought this was a great technique for solidifying basic comprehension of the material.

The subject matter and, certainly, the teaching style of the professor. Her passion for the subject matter, engagement of students in class, references to her personal life (which added a great twist to the course and kept it exciting), and both the professor and the t.a.'s availability to students were all good features of the course.

The readings were really interesting and enlightening. Also, I really appreciated Professor Carpenter's lectures on the material and thought her relation of the material to her experiences in the field really increased my understanding of the concepts.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: NA
The discussion section of class was too large to have an all-engaging discussion.
could be more focus on how these concepts can be applied in real life actions
The amount of reading each week is a little too much. Considering the entire work load, I think this class should be 4 credits.

As written above, the instructor is an excellent teacher and an amazing person. I wish Carol can teach two separate courses, one for Phd students, particularly for joint degree students, for whom the attendance is compulsory, and one for master students. Although the quality of the discussion is generally very high, the two groups have different concerns and experiences. In case that is not possible, I would prefer the course not to be compulsory for PhDs, and to maintain a quota of master and undergraduate comparable to PhDs.
nothing really

The one change I'd suggest making to the course syllabus is to include a little bit of Foucault, rather than just authors working within a Foucaultian school. To illustrate, while I thought we did a good job of working through Foucaultian ideas in the course lectures and discussions, when it came time to write my final paper, I found myself wanting to cite these concepts, but I realized I didn't have any course texts to go back to to look for specific citations from Foucault. It's a small detail, but since this is now a required course for joint FES-Anthro doctoral students, it seemed to me like a bit of a missed opportunity to engage with Foucault's key texts in the context of environment/development anthro.(That said, I DID like our use of the readings from Said, Scott, Gudeman&Rivera, and Mitchell -- these were exceedingly useful!)

The reading requirements were, at least to me, too heavy. If perhaps only one article was mandatory to read, while two being optional, (and hence a thesis sentence report for only one article per week -perhaps the student gets to choose from the 3 articles) then it would probably have been more realistic to properly read everything that was required.
There was a lot of reference to Foucoult in the course. Although challenging reading, I think it would have been useful to read some of his work.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: They are both very available and helpful.
Very, she was wonderful.
Availability was restricted to office hours.
very available and very helpful
Excellent, from both.
More than satisfactory.
Very responsive and helpful.

Carol gives an incredible amount of time for office hours, with half an hour per student. Moreover, once I could not meet her during office hours, and she met me for one hour an a very short notice, even if she is not my advisor.As written above, she is an extremely caring and thoughtful teacher.At one point, I had an emergency, and Carol went out of her way to help me in any possible way. Carol's presence makes FES a better place to learn and to live in.
Both instructor and TA were both wonderful and very helpful
Great help from both!
Both the instructor and TA were helpful in this regard throughout the semester.

Lauren provided a few paper workshopping sessions which I thought were really useful. I really appreciated the time she put into supporting students. Carol was also very helpful, though I didn't always feel that the 30 minute time slots provided for meeting with her were sufficient.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: I want to work in the development field, so this course gave me lots of new insights into the history and discourses that surround it. Before I do anything in my career, I will now stop to think about the motivations and possible impacts of it.
It completely changed my course of study, since I enjoyed the ideas so much.
This course is essential for anybody in FES doing any work related with social sciences.
This course fits into my overall concentration on international development and gave me a different perspective on the issue that I will take with me in future work in this field.
It matched my professional and academic directions and hence fit very well into my overall program.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Broadening my horizons.
To learn what happens to policy once it's out of the box
To help me understand social aspects of my research.
I heard wonderful things about Carol, and wanted to be sure to take her class before I graduated. I am glad I did. She is brilliant and is a wonderful lecturer and facilitator.
Because it is compulsory for me, but also because of the teacher, on whom I heard very good feedback. I am really glad I took the course even if I had taken a similar course several years before.
I was interested in the course content and heard great things.
In addition to being a topic relevant to my research, this is a required course for the joint FES-Anthro doctoral program.
Relation to professional direction, as well as being the instructor's advisee at the time.

I took this course because I was very interested in understanding the problems in development and conservation projects in the developing world are not achieving their intended goals, and how those projects could be improved to better achieve their goals.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes, and more!
Very much
yes
Yes, and then some. But there (inevitably?)is more about what goes wrong in human affairs than what goes right, although there is some uplifting material
Surpassed them.
Yes!
absolutely yes.
Yes.

Yes! I liked the scope and content of the readings, and the lectures were clear and helpful. That said, as my response above suggests, I do think that it might be worth doing some tinkering with the readings and course format to take into account the fact that this is now a required course for doctoral students (and that it will be covered on our comprehensive exams). I realize that this may be challenging, since it's a multi-level course, but I would've liked to have a somewhat meatier engagement with some of the ideas in the texts, or to have worked more systematically through their relationship to theoretical debates within anthropology (or, for that matter, environmental science) more broadly.
It passed my expectations, mostly due to the instructor's method of teaching.

I do feel I gained an understanding of the problems in development and conservation work. I feel, however, that the course focused a lot on the problems in development and conservation rather than the ways that it can be improved. I do feel that this better understanding of the problems will help me to more clearly identify important considerations when working on a development or conservation project.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: More than I would have expected.
More than I expected!
yes
Yes.
More.
Yes!
more than what expected.
Yes.
Yes -- I feel I came away from the course with a good introduction to the broad sweep of environment/development anthropology.
I got more out of it than i expected i would.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: NA
The work group held with other presenters was typically the day before and very unstructured.
It was nice to be able to lead class discussions and to talk about course readings with other students beforehand.
Advantages: learned from other students

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Do the readings.
Take it!
Take the time to really absorb the readings and you will get a lot out of the course.
Start the paper early if you can; it gets really interesting to apply what you are thinking to this course, but it takes time to develop that.
Start the final project as soon as possible. Give yourself time to enjoy the readings.
Take it! Everyone should take it! There are lots of work that people are doing at FES that would benefit from this class!

Understand the readings without thinking about the practice. Understnad first, the applicability will come later. Read more than what required, explore the recommended reading, the sillabus is very good.
Think about your final paper topic early
